awd_titl_txt: NSF Convergence Accelerator Track C: National Quantum Literacy Workforce Curriculum and Training Network
awd_abstract_narration:
The NSF Convergence Accelerator supports use-inspired, team-based, multidisciplinary efforts that address challenges of national importance and will produce deliverables of value to society in the near future. This project seeks to develop a national quantum literacy workforce network to broaden and increase participation. By applying fairness, ethics, accountability and transparency (FEAT) to develop quantum literacy frameworks, this project aims to engage diverse communities in quantum science. Partners include those from Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs), Minority Business Enterprises (MBEs), national laboratories, industry, and nonprofits who will develop a taxonomy, curriculum, training and national network to enhance quantum literacy at a national scale.

The project aims to increase the participation of historically underrepresented groups in quantum science through its diverse network as well as through its curriculum and training. The building of a national quantum literacy workforce ecosystem includes four pathways: (1) identifying quantum literacy taxonomic nomenclature utilized in industry settings; (2) conceptualizing a quantum literacy curriculum design informed by industry; (3) designing training modalities that are adaptable to various industries; and (4) building a national network of academics, businesses, nonprofits, government and national laboratories. The curriculum aims to be widely accessible and used by those in industry, students, academics as well as government and nonprofits. By assisting end-users to gain an understanding of the quantum concepts, this project will enhance a quantum literate communities. With a focus on building the network with those from HBCUs, MBEs, governments labs, industry, and nonprofits, this project aims to transform and strengthen the quantum workforce and will be a resource for those engaging in diversity efforts in quantum.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
During Phase 1 of the planning project, entitled the National Quantum Literary Workforce Curriculum and Training Network, the two main goals will focus, specifically, on developing a conceptual framework for (1) designing a prototype national network of academics, businesses, nonprofits, and national laboratories in need of a quantum literate workforce that will (2) develop a plan to build a national quantum literacy workforce ecosystem through the process of outlining a roadmap infrastructure focusing on four (4) critical pathways:

     1)    identifying a quantum literacy taxonomic nomenclature common to industries broadly,

     2)    conceptualizing a quantum literacy curriculum design that can incorporate diverse industry   sectors by specific quantum nomenclature needs,

     3)    designing prototype training modalities that are adaptable to diverse industries and workers and their unique skill sets, and

     4)    building a network of industry, academia, government, and nonprofits that become part of the quantum workforce ecosystem.

1.      Designing a Quantum Literacy Taxonomy

During Phase 1, the project team identified over 100 plus terms commonly used in quantum networks, sensors, computing, and quantum broadly. The Taxonomy Subcommittee was formed to identify and develop: unique language, categories, classifications, taxonomies, and assumptions. The team recognized that taxonomic terms served as the foundation for building curricula, training, and establishing networks. This applied to both STEM and non-STEM majors. The team further recognized that Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) were no different, but rather, were less likely to be invited to participate taxonomic development process. The Taxonomy Subcommittee develop a preliminary database to organize taxonomic terms and match the terms to specific characteristics, as summarized above.

2.              Quantum Literacy Team Building Strategy

            The team was structured as an interdisciplinary network, meaning that the team of  individuals contributed to the overall quality of the frameworks. For example, Objective 5 focused on organizing a conference webinar. We were fortunate in being invited, moderating, and organizing the first national panel of a Nobel Prize Laureate, Dr. William Phillips, and two of our minority business enterprise team members. They were part of the Black Engineer Year Award (BEYA) 2021 conference on quantum science. The conference webinar resulted in over 120 African American engineering students participating in the session Q&A. They focused on bringing together future engineering students who would recognize the importance of quantum literacy at each of the levels discussed. We were able to network with other convergent accelerated projects in advancing quantum literacy through workshops and seminars.

            The project’s vision, mission, goals and objectives set forth an important perspective and process in developing proof-of-concept frameworks for a national quantum literacy curriculum and training network. Specifically, the team focused on designing a roadmap for quantum literacy learners, as it was necessary to recognize the importance of building a talent pool of quantum literate individuals that would start at the K-12 level. This approach led to a roadmap that did not only include undergraduate and graduate education, but rather, also included workforce occupational levels and community college education. In addition, non-academic communities were explored to include business and industry, nonprofit, and government. To reiterate, this planning proposal was inclusive of academic and non-academic communities in developing frameworks for a quantum literacy curriculum and training network that supported the overall goals and objectives of Phase 1. This project involved team building strategies that helped to answer a series of questions, as presented during NSF coaching and presentations. 

2.              Quantum Literacy Curriculum Framework 

            This quantum literacy curriculum framework was intended to be used by anyone engaged in STEM education and comprises a diverse spectrum of learners, educators, and occupations. A content specific outline has been developed to include goals, objectives, and outcomes that are specifically linked to appropriate quantum literacy taxonomy and professional learning activities. 

Given this project was focused on planning during Phase 1, the project team was divided into four groups: 1) taxonomy, 2) curriculum, 3) training, and 4) professional networks. However, in building the plan across these four groups required the following critical activities to be undertaken by each group over the 9-month period of the project:

  • Participated in team activities that led to the development of preliminary curriculum framework(s), e.g., K-12, community colleges, etc.;
  • Participated in and supported all project activities that led to the development of a draft model for Quantum Literacy Curriculum Frameworks that are designed to educate, train and fuel the scientific pipeline in preparing the quantum workforce and ecosystem at all levels of industry and society at-large;
  • Develop a technical and community college networking protocol that has been used to start building a national network to establish an advisory board consisting of members from industry and academia, government with diverse expertise to articulate post-secondary training needs as well as increase awareness of opportunities for experiential learning, to develop and prepare a viable quantum-smart workforce; and
